wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup: 4/10/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

Reinventing Performance Management

A new Deloitte survey finds 58% of executives questioned believe that their current performance management approach drives neither employee engagement nor high performance ‘ and a shocking 2 millions hours are spent a year on performance management (think ratings, completing forms, meetings) at a single organization. The solution: something nimbler, real-time, and more individualized that fuels performance for the future rather than the past.

U.S. Employee Engagement Dips in March

After reaching a three-year average high in February, U.S. employee engagement dips to 31.7% according to Gallup. Their data also reveals another interesting trend, which finds female workers are significantly more engaged in their jobs than male ‘ 34.7% of females are engaged compared to 29.2% of males.

Why Are These 100 Companies The Best to Work For

What’s the common denominator behind Fortune‘s list of 100 Best Companies to Work For? In short, they are purpose driven workplaces ‘ many of the companies place a premium on providing opportunities for employees to give back. Increasingly, employees want to be inspired at work, contribute in a meaningful way, and be a part of – or experience – something larger.

Growing employee engagement with the network effect

During the recent GreenBiz Forum, WeSpire Founder and CEO, Susan Hunt Stevens, delivered a presentation using data visualization to show how social networks can drive sustainable actions. Over two years of data shows how companies can achieve exponential growth in their programs, and identifies the social catalysts driving engagement.

Aon Hewitt Study Reveals Strong Link Between Employee Engagement and Employee Perceptions of Total Rewards. Honest Leader Communication Also Influences Engagement

New survey data conducted by Aon Hewitt finds that 60% of engaged employees have total rewards (everything an employer provides to an employee, including pay, benefits and the work environment) are above or well above those who are disengaged. Another important gap that emerged between engaged and disengaged workers is how they perceive communication: “The most engaged employees are the ones who are encouraged to share ideas and who witness open, honest communication from senior leadership”.
